description: From Middle English turbide, borrowed from Latin turbidus (“disturbed”), from turba (“mass, throng, crowd, tumult, disturbance”).

adjectives.description: turbid (comparative more turbid, superlative most turbid)

entries.meaning: (of a liquid) Having the lees or sediment disturbed; not clear.
examples: He perceived more clearly the cruelty of Nature, to whom our refinement and piety are but as bubbles, hurrying downwards on the turbid waters.
Synonyms: fumid, hazy; see also Thesaurus:nebulous
Synonyms: ambiguous, equivocal; see also Thesaurus:incomprehensible, Thesaurus:vague
